description:
Babesia microti is a protozoan parasite that belongs to the phylum Apicomplexa. The strain RI (Rhode Island) is a specific genetic variant of B. microti that was first isolated from a human patient in Rhode Island, United States.

Babesia microti is an obligate intraerythrocytic parasite, meaning it can only replicate and survive within the red blood cells of its host. The RI strain is known to be one of the causative agents of human babesiosis, a tick-borne infectious disease.

The life cycle of B. microti RI involves transmission by the tick vector Ixodes scapularis, also known as the blacklegged tick or deer tick. The ticks acquire the parasite by feeding on infected reservoir hosts, such as white-tailed deer or small rodents. When the infected ticks subsequently feed on humans, they can transmit the B. microti RI strain, leading to the development of babesiosis.

Genetically, the RI strain of B. microti has been characterized and found to be distinct from other B. microti strains circulating in different geographical regions. This strain-specific information is important for epidemiological studies, diagnostic testing, and potential development of targeted treatment or prevention strategies.
